content:
Feedback from one user (not me) you are unlikely to see submitted:

it's [expletive] too long
I give up
Completing this survey should take about 10–30 minutes
too long

Another user:

IMO [the question about the playground is] biased: it's not an essential tool for experienced users because they can find other solutions for experimenting but it's an essential tool for enrolling, for new users to try things before they have a productive env, for sharing, for helping users on SO, etc. I think Rust can't not have a good and efficient playground even if I don't use it much myself

meta commentary: that user's first language is not English, so I'm not sure how strong to read "bias" literally
@Jake Goulding Mind if I move those two comments to the survey stream?
Not at all (I tried to find it on Zulip and this all I saw)
@Jake Goulding It's #t-community/rust-survey-2021.
Would you rather post them there or have me just move the last few messages there?
Feel free to move them
I guess the Zulip search doesn't cover unsubscribed channels (by default?)
I don't know.
This topic was moved here from #t-lang > 2021 survey by Josh Triplett

Jake Goulding said:

Feedback from one user (not me) you are unlikely to see submitted:

it's [expletive] too long
I give up
Completing this survey should take about 10–30 minutes
too long

Yea :frown: - Finding a balance between getting the right amount of information and not making it too long is tough. 30 minutes is really if you happen to need to fill out all free form answers which is unlikely. I wonder if we should have been less "exact" and said the survey should take roughly 10-15 minutes (which is likely true for almost everyone) to not set expectations that the survey could be really long.

Reddit also has some comments saying it's too long. I imagine almost any survey over a certain length will be too long for some people. It's hard to know what to do with the feedback other than try our best to not make it longer (and make it shorter if we can).
One thought on the survey. Asking newcomers and unexperienced users about changes during past year isn't a good idea.
That's fair. I believe we used to do this even more so I would say we're an improvement over previous iterations, but definitely something to keep track off.
Speaking of which, we need to make issues out of these.

Do you agree with the following statements on Rust employment?

It might be worth to add Unsure option here since not all even tried to search for jobs in Rust.
Should issue be grouped or not? For example, there are a few questions which for newcomers might be hard to answer.
I think you can create one issue for questions which are asked to newcomers and should not be
https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys/issues/185
Maybe move questions about personal use of Rust before Company/Job related questions, and skip the latter entirely if user has no Rust Job (like hobbyists or outsourced freelancers)?

Unless the survey logic is broken, the "To what extent is Rust currently being used by your company?" and "Are you using Rust at work?" questions should route folks who don't have Rust Jobs past the company/job related questions.
The "When did you learn to program rust" feels like a strange question. I don't know how to answer it, in part because "learning rust" isn't a discrete event that I can put a timestamp on

The fact that we have 5k answers and a handful of complaints about length mean we should take it with a grain of salt, I think. And maybe adjusting the estimate would be good, and just saying "average".
Looking at the survey data, the average completion time is 16:49 minutes - right in line with the 10-25 in the header. Once it's closed, I can see if there are any trends or actionable insights.
Are you able to track how many people started the survey but didn't complete it?

Right now we have an about 75.6% completion rate, which is good. I haven't dug in to see at what point those attempts end (there's always a solid chunk who click on the survey and leave before even really starting).
I don't remember what the earlier surveys were
not sure if the historic data is still around

a handful of complaints

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survivorship_bias
I tried to find the old completion rate, but I don't think Google supplies that.
FWIW we are already nearly at the total number of responses we had for the 2020 survey so in terms of total number of responses it doesn't seem like we're seeing too much of an issue.
Granted due to increased popularity it is possible we should see even more responses this year.
But I think it's safe to say that the length of the survey is not detrimental to our ability to collect data
Whether or not we would have gotten more responses if the survey had been X% shorter is harder to say though

Looking closely at the few stats that SurveyHero provide. 78% of folks who open the survey, "participate" in the survey (I'm not sure what the definition is but I believe it is "answers one question at least"). 76% finish the survey. So we have a large drop off after opening (which in my opinion is very much to be expected) and a small drop off from starting to finishing. I think this is really great news
We're up to over 8000 responses as well which is really great (last year we had ~6K)
That sounds like an incredible response rate.
Losing only 2% of people over the course of the survey seems quite good.

And "losing" 22% of people who just open the link seems normal, given that many people may just want to read the initial information to see what it is and then decide they don't want to take the time.
(or, like me, they open the survey on one machine, and decide to take it on another machine)
yeah, or open on their phones and switch or something
8000 is amazing. I'm guessing the data has completely settled at this point?

JT [they/them] said:

8000 is amazing. I'm guessing the data has completely settled at this point?

Not sure what you mean by settled, but the response rate is low. We did get 41 responses yesterday which is still an all-time low
We should probably do a reminder round of promotion since it closes in a couple of days

Josh Triplett said:

Losing only 2% of people over the course of the survey seems quite good.

So I took a deeper look at raw numbers and unfortunately this isn't the case (SurveyHero's descriptions are really poor). It turns out 76% of those who start the survey, finish it. So we have a 24% drop off from starting to ending. This could be better, but I don't think it's a horrible percentage.

Nick Cameron said:

We should probably do a reminder round of promotion since it closes in a couple of days

https://twitter.com/ryan_levick/status/1472963192833855491

There's on a few days left to fill out the Rust annual survey! Make sure you take some time to give the project feedback and input! :tada: https://twitter.com/ryan_levick/status/1468898509197828097

- Ryan Levick (@ryan_levick)
I did a similar tweet earlier too

Are you currently, or have you in the last year, taken a course or training which uses or teaches Rust?

Where's the answer specifically tailored for me? :-)
@Josh Triplett @rylev That completion rate is right in line with the expected rate for a survey of this size/complexity (it's actually on the higher end)
